speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.2: High School Renovation Project - The board will consider approval of funding for major facility improvements at the high school, including building four new science laboratories and repairing the athletic fields. The science lab construction is projected to cost $1,240,400 spread over four years, while athletic field repairs are included in the same package. These upgrades aim to improve STEM instruction and student access to safe extracurricular facilities.. Who would like to start?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I'd like to offer some context before we discuss the budget. We're aware that our current labs don't meet industry standards; as a result, students miss out on quality learning experiences. Additionally, safety concerns have forced us to cancel outdoor activities regularly due to poor athletic field conditions. This project can help bridge these gaps and ensure every student has equal opportunities to excel academically and athletically. Kate, may I ask you to summarize key points from your assessment of the proposal?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Jon, thank you for setting the stage. Based on my review, it appears the proposal aligns with our strategic goals and addresses critical needs. Specifically, I see value in phasing the laboratory renovations over four years to minimize disruptions and maintain fiscal responsibility. I also appreciate how the plan incorporates both instructional enhancements (STEM) and health-related benefits through improved athletic facilities. Have any of you considered potential partnerships or grants to supplement our investment and further leverage resources?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thank you, Kate, for summarizing your analysis so concisely. Your point about exploring partnership possibilities resonates with me too. David Oberg, could you comment briefly on whether grant opportunities were explored during the planning process and if there might be ways to collaborate with local organizations or educational institutions moving forward? And Graham Page, perhaps you could confirm whether our proposed timeline allows enough flexibility should additional funds become available?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Absolutely, Katrina. Our team did research and identify several potential grants and collaborations. One possibility is partnering with nearby universities to secure expertise and potentially access more advanced equipment. While these discussions are still preliminary, they hold promise. Regarding the timeline, Graham, I believe it's essential to prioritize phasing and ensure we're prepared to adapt if supplemental funding emerges. This way, we can seize those opportunities without disrupting the overall project's momentum. Graham, could you elaborate on the built-in flexibility within the proposed schedule?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Yes, thanks Dave. Indeed, our design includes multiple checkpoints and opportunities to reassess priorities throughout the next three years. If new revenue sources emerge or stakeholder input suggests shifts in need, then we've built into the plan enough agility to adjust timelines, phase scope, or reallocate dollars accordingly. So rest assured we'll stay receptive to future collaborative or funding opportunities as they arise., Judyle?, do you want to contribute something here?   Kate Acuff just mentioned staying connected and talking strategically. What advice would you give regarding an ongoing dialogue on where else we may find support.? How do we build strong bonds?  For example, what kinds of partners might we look at to make sure we get better than our million-dollar request and continue working towards the outcomes we have set for ourselves in terms of being in good shape financially long-term.? Can I tell them a story? At one time I served on the United Way Board locally. During my first year as chair, they had never received $10 million total, but after five months we hit $11.7 million because of strong communication efforts. That is a lesson which carries forward now when we communicate well internally.  You see, if we cannot articulate what is needed in our schools to our kids effectively and why they deserve no less, then our children suffer unnecessarily. A compelling case must be made as we share our vision externally and internally, right down to staff members who interact daily with students. When everyone shares ownership by understanding their roles in supporting each other and all learners, then results happen.  As for fostering connections between stakeholders such as UVA, Albemarle County Service Authority, or even private enterprise, maintaining open lines of communication helps foster mutually beneficial relationships. In fact, hosting business roundtables and community events creates a rich environment for sharing our aspirations with others passionate about enhancing public education. All parties involved are thus positioned for success while pursuing common objectives. Would someone describe another scenario in which collaboration bore fruit around here recently? Davidoberg?: Well, I was pleased by last week's meeting involving Jack Jewett discussing his idea with a cross section of people from all walks of life in the county who shared perspectives on youth challenges we currently face. Collaboration certainly helped spark fresh ideas addressing them. One positive outcome of Mr. Johnson's challenge gift to ACPS Foundation focusing on innovation already led us down new paths to expand educational options to deserving students outside traditional boundaries. To date, they raised $125000 as he committed

speaker: davidoberg
content: Judy, I couldn't agree more about the importance of effective communication and collaboration. Your United Way experience serves as a great reminder of what can be achieved through strong relationships and a clear vision. I'm glad you brought up the recent meeting with Jack Jewett, as it demonstrates our capacity for convening diverse stakeholders to tackle pressing issues. Building on that momentum, I propose we establish a dedicated task force to explore potential partnerships and grant opportunities, ensuring we capitalize on emerging chances to enhance our STEM offerings and student services. Ellen Osborne, given your experience with community outreach, would you be willing to co-chair this task force with me? By pooling our collective strengths, I'm confident we can create a robust network of supporters invested in the success of our students and schools.

speaker: judyle
content: David, I think that's an excellent suggestion, and I applaud your willingness to take on a leadership role in driving this effort forward. Ellen, I'd love to hear your thoughts on co-chairing the task force, but I'd like to add that we should consider including representatives from local businesses, higher education institutions, and civic organizations to ensure diverse perspectives and strengthen our collective impact. By doing so, we can leverage their expertise, resources, and networks to amplify our initiatives and ultimately benefit our students.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Completely concur with Judy and David; establishing this task force will facilitate the identification and pursuit of promising collaborations and funding sources. I suggest we also engage with regional economic development entities, like the Charlottesville-Albemarle Chamber of Commerce, to tap into their knowledge and resources. They often possess valuable insights into existing and prospective industries requiring skilled STEM professionals. Let's make certain that our joint effort aligns with workforce needs in the region, thereby bolstering our appeal to potential partners. Furthermore, by demonstrating this alignment, we reinforce the value proposition for investing in our students' futures.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I wholeheartedly endorse the proposal for a dedicated task force to explore partnerships and grant opportunities. I am honored to co-chair this endeavor alongside David, leveraging our combined expertise to cultivate meaningful relationships and secure vital resources for our students. I agree that inclusivity is key, and incorporating representatives from local businesses, higher education institutions, and civic organizations will enrich our collective approach. Additionally, engaging with regional economic development entities, as Kate suggested, will help us tailor our initiatives to meet the evolving workforce demands in our area.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: With such a talented team taking on this critical work, I believe that our possibilities truly become endless. Herein lies yet another testament to how far-reaching the influence of successful community engagement can stretch. Thank you all for recognizing the significance of nurturing these crucial ties. As this task force takes form, I recommend that we keep our focus sharp on both short-term goals and longer-term horizons. Our immediate aims of securing additional funding and constructing cutting-edge facilities will serve as powerful catalysts, paving the way for deeper collaboration down the road. In our quest for greater financial sustainability, let's remain agile, continually evaluating lessons learned along the way and adapting to any shifting landscapes. And, most importantly, remember that every step taken today will directly impact our cherished students tomorrow. So as the journey unfolds, I encourage each of you to hold close the image of those young minds we're empowering – ever curious, increasingly equipped, and forever grateful. Thank you again for leading by example. Now, before moving ahead further, could Graham Page clarify what sort of milestones or key performance indicators you envision us using to monitor progress during this multi-year process? This detail is pivotal in order to maintain accountability among ourselves, our constituents, and the larger community. It’s essential for us all to stay focused on exactly what we aim to achieve and measure in both the near term and beyond. By embracing quantifiable metrics, transparency becomes easier and trust builds within our circle. The end result is that our entire system benefits. Thank you, Graham. Your guidance here really will prove invaluable in keeping everyone grounded and oriented correctly.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Jon, thank you so much for that. I appreciate your emphasis on staying attuned to long-range goals while measuring tangible outcomes throughout our pursuit of enhanced educational experiences via STEM expansion. While planning unfolds, we must pinpoint salient benchmarks to gauge advancements toward our ambitious objectives. For instance, monitoring total dollars secured via grants, number of collaborative agreements brokered with external organizations, and the amount of hours spent by volunteer mentors with our students will offer insightful windows into our collective progress. Moreover, periodically reviewing student academic achievements, school-to-workforce readiness rates, and teacher satisfaction levels connected to upgraded infrastructure and expanded curricula will provide quantitative validation of the positive impacts wrought by targeted investments. I have confidence in our team members and look forward to witnessing firsthand the profound improvements to come. We’re going to need an update next month at the February board meeting. Can you give me a brief report then regarding where you are at the time? And if there are no other comments or questions at this point, we'll go ahead and move onto our final topic. Are there any other items that anyone wants to discuss prior to our adjournment tonight? Dave, did you want to say anything else on that one?katrina: If I may, Jon, just real quick. Also perhaps maybe we need something that measures whether or not there is a better understanding in terms of workforce pipeline across different sectors. What I mean is that when looking at those things, are we seeing a shift in the number of kids who graduate and head straight away into tech careers? That kind of measurement might be important for us too. I didn’t know if you were thinking along those lines, but wanted to throw that out there because it seems quite relevant.jonnoalcaro: Absolutely, Katrina. Thanks for adding that extra layer of depth. Monitoring changes over time related to students entering specific fields post-graduation will afford compelling evidence regarding our capacity for creating a well-prepared, highly adaptable talent pool responsive to local industry requirements. Adding that dimension enhances the integrity of our comprehensive assessment framework. I completely agree with your suggestion, Katrina. Thank you for offering it.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content:
And in terms of reporting back at the February meeting, would you prefer that we have a detailed written report ready or simply an oral update, Mr. Paige? And if a document is needed, should we distribute it in advance of the session so that folks may digest information beforehand?
```

speaker: grahampaige
content: Good question, Katrina. At this stage, I think an oral report accompanied by some very limited supporting materials like two slides summarizing the data points we've discussed would suffice. Please do distribute the slides at least a week before the February board meeting. This will enable review and questions prior to our discussion that night. Then you can supplement your remarks accordingly. Does that sound right to everyone involved with the partnership task force? Ellen, David, did I capture everything accurately?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Yes, Graham, that sounds perfect. Oral updates supported by concise visual aids will ensure clarity without overwhelming the board. Distribution a week in advance will allow for thorough review, facilitating more productive discussions during the meeting. I'm confident this format will effectively communicate our progress and next steps.

speaker: grahampaige
content: All righty then. Moving now to new business. There was nothing mentioned, so I'd like to open up the floor for any new announcements or matters from Dr. Haas. Do you have anything, John? No other topics coming from board members either? Then we'll wrap up tonight. Is there a motion to approve our consent agenda? Second? Moved by Ms. Lee and second by Dr. Alcaro. May we please hear yeses or nos to signal approval of the consent agenda? Seeing none opposed, that concludes the actions required from this session. Thank you all for being present and participating actively. We stand adjourned effective immediately. Happy Thanksgiving! See you guys in December.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Thank you everyone for voting. After counting all the votes, we have 7 (public) / 6 (private) in favor, 0 (public) / 0 (private) against, and 0 (public) / 1 (private) abstaining. Results → Public: approved, Private: approved, Combined: approved. Thank you everyone for coming, have a nice night.
